texts.shortText: The largest and best known of all regional algae and an iconic feature of the west coast. The large, conical holdfast is comprised of a network of cylindrical, branched, root-like haptera. This gives rise to a long, hollow stipe that arises from a thin base and then swells distally, ending in a gas-filled bulb that buoys the fronds to the surface. Primary frond ribbon-shaped in juveniles, but becomes broadly triangular in adults and gives rise to long, strap-like secondary blades along its margins. Spores are borne on raided patches on the blades.
Total length varies with water depth, as stipe stops growing when fronds reach surface. Typically about 5 m, but can reach up to 15 m.

Global: Southern African endemic.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about Cape Agulhas, but is spreading eastwards as a result of climate change and recently reported from De Hoop.

Forms extensive beds that extend from the low water mark to about 10 m depth. Since the gas-filled stipe raises the fronds to the water surface the beds are very visible and are a prominent feature of the west coast.

Play numerous important roles, including protection of the coastline from wave action and acting as a substratum for numerous smaller species, many of which occur only on this one host species. Kelp beds support a rich and diverse community of understory algae, invertebrate and fish species that include commercially important species, such as rock-lobsters and abalone. Some of these have an obligate relationship with the kelps and are found nowhere else.

Kelp wrack washed up on adjacent beaches also supports a rich and diverse fauna of beach-hoppers, isopods, kelp flies, etc.

Kelps are also directly harvested to feed farmed abalone and for production of an agricultural growth stimulant. Young fronds are also edible and can be used to make delicious kelp noodles!
Alternating generations of the familiar large spore-producing sporophytes and separate microscopic male and female gametophytes.

Sometimes confused with the Split-fan kelp Laminaria pallida, which occurs in mixed beds, but that species has a solid stipe with no terminal bulb and a single, flat frond that is split into parallel straps.
